content.text: Define acceleration
Use
State Newton's first law of motion
Calculate the distance travelled by the parachutist in the first 3.0s of the motion
distance = .........m
Explain the variation of the resultant force acting on the parachutist from \(t = 0\) (point A) to \(t = 15 \text{s}\) (point C)
Describe the changes to the frictional force on the parachutist
1. at \(t = 15 \text{s}\) (point C),
2. between \(t = 15 \text{s}\) (point C) and \(t = 22 \text{s}\) (point E)
The mass of the parachutist is \(95\mathrm{kg}\)
Calculate, for the parachutist between \(t = 15 \text{s}\) (point C) and \(t = 17 \text{s}\) (point D),
1. the average acceleration,
acceleration = .........$\text{m s}^{-2}$
2. the average frictional force
frictional force = .........N
The variation with time \(t\) of vertical speed \(v\) of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1
Define electrical resistance
Draw a circuit diagram of the apparatus that could be used to make these measurements
Readings for p.d. \(V\) and the corresponding current \(I\) are obtained. These are shown in Fig. 2.1
Use data from Fig. 2.1 to determine \(R.\) Explain your working
A circuit is set up to measure the resistance \(R\) of a metal wire. The potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the wire and the current \(I\) in the wire are to be measured
In another experiment, a value of \(R\) is determined from the following data:
Current \(I = 0.64 \pm 0.01 \text{A}\) and p.d. \(V = 6.8 \pm 0.1 \text{V}\)
Calculate the value of \(R,\) together with its uncertainty. Give your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures
Define pressure
Explain, in terms of the air molecules, why the pressure at the top of a mountain is less than at sea level
Calculate the weight of the column of liquid
weight = .........N
Calculate the pressure on the base of the container caused by the weight of the liquid
pressure = .........Pa
Explain why the pressure exerted on the base of the container is different from the value calculated in (ii)
Fig. 3.1 shows a liquid in a cylindrical container
The cross-sectional area of the container is \(0.450 \text{m}^2\). The height of the column of liquid is \(0.250 \text{m}\) and the density of the liquid is \(13600 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Describe the diffraction of monochromatic light as it passes through a diffraction grating
Describe how the principle of superposition is used to explain
1. white light at the zero order,
2. the difference in position of red and blue light in the first-order spectrum
Light of wavelength 625 nm produces a second-order maximum at an angle of \(61.0^{\circ}\) to the incident direction
Determine the number of lines per metre of the diffraction grating
number of lines = .........m$^{-1}$
Calculate the wavelength of another part of the visible spectrum that gives a maximum for a different order at the same angle as in (ii)
wavelength = ..........nm
White light is incident on a diffraction grating, as shown in Fig. 4.1
The diffraction pattern formed on the screen has white light, called zero order, and coloured spectra in other orders
Explain what is meant by plastic deformation
Calculate the breaking force of the wire
breaking force = .........N
A stress of \(9.0 \times 10^7 \text{Pa}\) is applied to the wire. Calculate the extension
extension = .........m

A copper wire of uniform cross-sectional area \(1.54 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}^2\) and length \(1.75 \text{m}\) has a breaking stress of \(2.20 \times 10^8 \text{Pa}\). The Young modulus of copper is \(1.20 \times 10^{11} \text{Pa}\)
Explain why it is not appropriate to use the Young modulus to determine the extension when the breaking force is applied
Describe the structure of an atom of the nuclide \(^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U}\)
Explain why the apparatus is enclosed in a vacuum
State and explain the readings detected by D when it is moved along WXY
Question 6 continues on page 16
The deflection of \(\alpha\) -particles by a thin metal foil is investigated with the arrangement shown in Fig. 6.1. All the apparatus is enclosed in a vacuum
The detector of \(\alpha\) -particles, D, is moved around the path labelled WXY
A beam of \(\alpha\) -particles produces a current of 1.5pA. Calculate the number of \(\alpha\) -particles per second passing a point in the beam
